facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 194 of 1961 in Civil Appellate Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION , Civil Appeal No. 194 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 28, 1959 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in C.M.A. No. 120 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 28, 1959 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court at Hyderabad in C. M. A. No. 120 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 11, 1963 by HIDAYATULLAH J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. February 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH.J.-The respondent who is the wife of the appellant obtained a decree

facts.text: Respondent is the wife of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent who is the wife of the appellant obtained a decree for maintenance on August 9, 1949,

facts.text: Respondent obtained decree for maintenance on August 9, 1949 ordering appellant to pay Rs. 3,000 per year on 28th February every year with 6% interest if not paid on due date.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent who is the wife of the appellant obtained a decree for maintenance on August 9, 1949, by which the appellant was ordered to pay Rs. 3,000/- per year to her on the 28th day of February of every year with interest at 6 per year if the payment was number made on the due date.

facts.text: Decree created charge for past and future maintenance on three lots of properties.

anchor.surface_text: The decree included ascertained amounts as arrears of past maintenance and other items to which detailed reference is number necessary. In addition to the personal liability the decree created a charge for past and future maintenance on three lots of properties.

facts.text: Respondent filed execution petition No. 91 of 1952 to bring charged properties to sale.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed execution petition No. 91 of 1952 for execution of the maintenance decree and sought to bring the properties charged by the decree to sale.

facts.text: Respondent purchased two items of charged properties for Rs. 20,200 subject to maintenance charge after obtaining court permission.

anchor.surface_text: She purchased two items of the properties charged by the decree to sale. she purchased two items of the properties for a sum of Rs. 20,200 subject to her maintenance charge after obtaining the permission of the Court.

facts.text: Respondent filed execution No. 43 of 1955 seeking sale of properties other than those purchased by her earlier.

anchor.surface_text: Later she filed execution No. 43 of 1955 seeking to bring to sale properties other than those purchased by her in the earlier execution.

facts.text: Appellant filed application under s.47 CPC to record full satisfaction of decree.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also filed an application under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure to record full satisfaction of the decree on the ground that the respondent by purchasing the properties subject to her charge companyld number maintain a fresh application for the sale of the other properties.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge of Visakhapatnam upheld appellant's contention and dismissed execution petition as not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate judge of Visakhapatnam upheld the companytention of the appellant and dismissed the execution petition as number maintainable.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court reversed Subordinate Judge's decision and ordered execution to proceed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reversed the decision of the Subordinate judge and ordered the execution to proceed.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court and appealed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has number appealed after obtaining special leave from this Court.

facts.text: In first execution, amounts due up to June 28, 1952 realised by sale of properties lots 1 and 2.

anchor.surface_text: When the first execution was levied the amounts due up to June 28, 1952, were realised by the sale of the properties of lots 1 and 2.

facts.text: Respondent as auction-purchaser deposited Rs. 6,010 towards balance of purchase price after deducting maintenance amount.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent as the auction-purchaser deposited Rs. 6,010 towards the balance of the purchase price after deducting the maintenance amount under the decree as it then stood.

facts.text: Present execution concerns sum due between June 28, 1952 and February 28, 1955, including Rs. 8,000 maintenance and Rs. 867-8-0 costs.

anchor.surface_text: The present execution companycerns the sum which fell due between June 28, 1952, and February 28, 1955. Included in this sum are Rs. 8,000 towards maintenance and Rs. 867-8-0 towards companyts.

facts.text: Appellant contends respondent must look only to purchased properties for maintenance claim.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellant companytends that the respondent must number look to the properties purchased by her for satisfaction of her claim in respect of maintenance past or future.

facts.text: Appellant alternatively contends execution against his properties cannot proceed till respondent proceeds against her purchased properties.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative lie companytends that execution against the properties in his possession cannot proceed till the respondent has first proceeded against the properties with her.

facts.text: Maintenance decree is declaratory and executory, providing Rs.3000 per year as long as respondent lives.

anchor.surface_text: The maintenance decree passed by the Subordinate judge of Visakhapatnam is number only a declaratory decree but also an executory decree. It provides that the appellant shall pay to the respondent Rs. 3,000 per year as maintenance on the 28th day of February of every year as long as she lives.

facts.text: Charge subsists on all originally charged properties as long as decree subsists.

anchor.surface_text: An executory charge-decree for maintenance becomes executable again and again as future sums become due. The executability of the decree keeps the charge alive on the remaining properties originally charged till the future amounts cease. In other words the charge subsists as long as the decree subsists.

facts.text: Decree can be personally executed against appellant but question not arisen.

anchor.surface_text: We express numberopinion on the question whether the decree can be personally executed against the appellant because that question did number arise here.

concepts.interpretation: Charge for maintenance subsists on all originally charged properties jointly and severally as long as executory decree subsists; not extinguished or transferred by partial purchase in execution.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: The whole of the charge companytinues over all the properties jointly and severally. Nor is any priority established between the properties purchased

concepts.unlisted_description: Charge on properties under maintenance decree remains enforceable on unsold portions for future dues.

anchor.surface_text: A charge is different from a mortgage. A mortgage is a transfer of an interest in property while a charge is merely a right to receive payment out of some specified property. The former is described as jus in rem and the latter as only a jus ad rem. In the case of a simple mortgage, there is a personal liability express or implied but in the case of charge there is nosuch personal liability and the decree, if it seeks to charge the judgment-debtor personally, has to do so in addition to the charge.

concepts.interpretation: Charge gives only jus ad rem (right against property), no transfer of interest unlike mortgage (jus in rem); no implied personal liability unlike simple mortgage.

concepts.unlisted_description: Security right to payment from specified property without transfer of interest.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing in law which requires the respondent to proceed against the properties which she had earlier purchased. There is numberquestion of marshalling of these properties.

concepts.interpretation: No requirement for charge-holder to marshal or exhaust self-purchased charged properties before proceeding against judgment-debtor's remaining properties.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Court may decide which of the properties charged should be sold and in what order and the Court does choose between different properties when ordering sale. To that extent the Court can assist a judgment-debtor. But this can only be in respect of the properties which the judgment-debtor holds and against which the charge-holder wants to proceed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number permissible to seek an analogy from the case of a mortgage. A charge is different from a mortgage. A mortgage is a transfer of an interest in property while a charge is merely a right to receive payment out of some specified property. The former is described as jus in rem and the latter as only a jus ad rem. In the case of a simple mortgage, there is a personal liability express or implied but in the case of charge there is nosuch personal liability and the decree, if it seeks to charge the judgment-debtor personally, has to do so in addition to the charge.

holdings.text: In our opinion neither proposition is correct.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion neither proposition is correct. The maintenance decree passed by the Subordinate judge of Visakhapatnam is not only a declaratory decree but also an executory decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects appellant's claims of full satisfaction and restriction to purchased properties due to executory nature of decree.

holdings.text: The maintenance decree is not only a declaratory decree but also an executory decree providing for annual maintenance as long as respondent lives.

anchor.surface_text: The maintenance decree passed by the Subordinate judge of Visakhapatnam is not only a declaratory decree but also an executory decree. It provides that the appellant shall pay to the respondent Rs. 3,000 per year as maintenance on the 28th day of February of every year as long as she lives.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree requires recurring payments, executable periodically.

holdings.text: An executory charge-decree for maintenance becomes executable again and again as future sums become due. The executability of the decree keeps the charge alive on the remaining properties originally charged till the future amounts cease. In other words the charge subsists as long as the decree subsists.

anchor.surface_text: An executory charge-decree for maintenance becomes executable again and again as future sums become due. The executability of the decree keeps the charge alive on the remaining properties originally charged till the future amounts cease. In other words the charge subsists as long as the decree subsists.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ongoing executability preserves charge on all original properties for future dues.

holdings.text: By the execution the charge is not transferred in its entirety to the properties purchased by the charge-holder. Nor is the charge divided between those properties and those which still remain with the judgment debtor. The whole of the charge continues over all the properties jointly and severally. Nor is any priority established between the properties purchased by the charge-holder and those that remain.

anchor.surface_text: By the execution the charge is not transferred in its entirety to the properties purchased by the charge-holder. Nor is the charge divided between those properties and those which still remain with the judgment debtor. The whole of the charge continues over all the properties jointly and severally.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge remains undivided and joint over all properties post partial execution sale.

holdings.text: A charge is different from a mortgage. A mortgage is a transfer of an interest in property while a charge is merely a right to receive payment out of some specified property. The former is described as jus in rem and the latter as only a jus ad rem. In the case of a simple mortgage, there is a personal liability express or implied but in the case of charge there is no such personal liability and the decree, if it seeks to charge the judgment-debtor personally, has to do so in addition to the charge.

anchor.surface_text: A charge is different from a mortgage. A mortgage is a transfer of an interest in property while a charge is merely a right to receive payment out of some specified property. The former is described as jus in rem and the latter as only a jus ad rem.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes charge (jus ad rem, no transfer or implied personal liability) from mortgage to reject merger analogy.

holdings.text: The charge can be enforced against all the properties or severally. In the present case the respondent could proceed at her option to recover the arrears of maintenance as they fell due from any of the properties which were the subject of the charge, that is to say, those which were in the possession and ownership of the appellant and those in the possession and ownership as auction-purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: The charge can be enforced against all the properties or severally. In the present case the respondent could proceed at her option to recover the arrears of maintenance as they fell due from any of the properties which were the subject of the charge, that is to say, those which were in the possession and ownership of the appellant and those in the possession and ownership as auction-purchaser.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge-holder has option to enforce against any charged property, including self-acquired via auction.

holdings.text: There is nothing in law which requires the respondent to proceed against the properties which she had earlier purchased. There is no question of marshalling of these properties.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in law which requires the respondent to proceed against the properties which she had earlier purchased. There is no question of marshalling of these properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No legal duty or marshalling doctrine compels exhausting own purchased properties first.

holdings.text: It is true that the Court may decide which of the properties charged should be sold and in what order and the Court does choose between different properties when ordering sale. To that extent the Court can assist a judgment-debtor. But this can only be in respect of the properties which the judgment-debtor holds and against which the charge-holder wants to proceed.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Court may decide which of the properties charged should be sold and in what order and the Court does choose between different properties when ordering sale. To that extent the Court can assist a judgment-debtor. But this can only be in respect of the properties which the judgment-debtor holds and against which the charge-holder wants to proceed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executing court's discretion limited to ordering sale of judgment-debtor's properties, not charge-holder's.

holdings.text: In our opinion the respondent was entitled to proceed against the remaining properties in the hands of the appellant which continued charged. The executing court may, of course, sell only such items as may be sufficient to meet the present dues under the decree but the appellant cannot insist that the respondent should proceed against the properties acquired by her under the first sale.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the respondent was entitled to proceed against the remaining properties in the hands of the appellant which continued charged. The executing court may, of course, sell only such items as may be sufficient to meet the present dues under the decree but the appellant cannot insist that the respondent should proceed against the properties acquired by her under the first sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms right to execute against remaining charged properties without prior exhaustion of purchased ones.

holdings.text: We express no opinion on the question whether the decree can be personally executed against the appellant because that question did not arise here.

anchor.surface_text: We express no opinion on the question whether the decree can be personally executed against the appellant because that question did not arise here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not arising in facts, hence not decided.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the respondent was entitled to proceed against the remaining properties in the hands of the appellant which continued charged. anchor.surface_text: The maintenance decree passed by the Subordinate judge of Visakhapatnam is not only a declaratory decree but also an executory decree. It provides that the appellant shall pay to the respondent Rs. 3,000 per year as maintenance on the 28th day of February of every year as long as she lives.

In our opinion the respondent was entitled to proceed against the remaining properties in the hands of the appellant which continued charged. The executing court may, of course, sell only such items as may be sufficient to meet the present dues under the decree but the appellant cannot insist that the respondent should

anchor.surface_text: An executory charge-decree for maintenance becomes executable again and again as future sums become due. The executability of the decree keeps the charge alive on the remaining properties originally charged till the future amounts cease. In other words the charge subsists as long as the decree subsists.

In our opinion the respondent was entitled to proceed against the remaining properties in the hands of the appellant which continued charged. The executing court may, of course, sell only such items as may be sufficient to meet the present dues under the decree but the appellant cannot insist that the respondent should

anchor.surface_text: By the execution the charge is not transferred in its entirety to the properties purchased by the charge-holder. Nor is the charge divided between those properties and those which still remain with the judgment debtor. The whole of the charge continues over all the properties jointly and severally.

In our opinion the respondent was entitled to proceed against the remaining properties in the hands of the appellant which continued charged. anchor.surface_text: A charge is different from a mortgage. A mortgage is a transfer of an interest in property while a charge is merely a right to receive payment out of some specified property. The former is described as jus in rem and the latter as only a jus ad rem.

anchor.surface_text: The charge can be enforced against all the properties or severally. In the present case the respondent could proceed at her option to recover the arrears of maintenance as they fell due from any of the properties which were the subject of the charge, that is to say, those which were in the possession and ownership of the appellant and those in the possession and ownership as auction-purchaser.

In our opinion the respondent was entitled to proceed against the remaining properties in the hands of the appellant which continued charged. anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Court may decide which of the properties charged should be sold and in what order and the Court does choose between different properties when ordering sale. To that extent the Court can assist a judgment-debtor. But this can only be in respect of the properties which the judgment-debtor holds and against which the charge-holder wants to proceed.
